meanings.definition: To surpass in barring or excluding.
meanings.sent1: She managed to outbar all the other candidates from entering the competition.
meanings.sent2: The security guard had to outbar the intruder from accessing the restricted area.
meanings.sent3: The clever squirrel outbarred the birds from the bird feeder by building a better defense.
meanings.sent4: His determination to outbar any obstacles in his way was like a strong fortress.
meanings.sent5: The knight's shield was like a magical barrier, able to outbar any enemy attack.

meanings.definition: To prevent from entering or gaining access.
meanings.sent1: The locked gate will outbar anyone without the key from entering the garden.
meanings.sent2: The bouncer had to outbar the underage individuals from entering the club.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous cat tried to outbar the dog from entering its favorite sleeping spot.
meanings.sent4: Her determination to outbar distractions was like wearing blinders to focus on her work.
meanings.sent5: The strong password was able to outbar any unauthorized users from accessing the account.

meanings.definition: To shut out or exclude from a place or group.
meanings.sent1: The exclusive club would outbar anyone who did not meet their strict membership criteria.
meanings.sent2: The clique of friends decided to outbar the new student from joining their group.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous raccoon tried to outbar the other animals from entering its den.
meanings.sent4: His loud music outbarred any chance of hearing the approaching storm outside.
meanings.sent5: The high walls of the fortress outbarred any invaders from entering the kingdom.
